about.pageDescription: Learn about the philosophy of Sentiment Inside Out and how simple analysis tools can turn market sentiment into key investment indicators, helping investors overcome fear and greed.
about.keywords: market sentiment, investment psychology, fear and greed, investment indicators, sentiment analysis, investment strategy
about.ogTitle: About Sentiment Inside Out - Market Sentiment Analysis Platform
about.heading: About Sentiment Inside Out
about.section1Text: This is a famous quote from Andr√© Kostolany, author of 'The Speculator's Confession'. Funds = Fundamentals = Macroeconomics. Psychology = Investor Sentiment = Human Nature. I believe cycles stem from human irrationality, creating the peaks and troughs of the economy and stock market.
about.section2Text: Economic data and company reports change monthly or quarterly, yet the capital market can fluctuate dramatically in short periods. This shows that sentiment's impact on price is no less than fundamentals. Some sell fearing it's too expensive; others buy fearing they'll miss out. As market participants, we should understand whether the market is currently in a state of fear or greed.
about.section3Text: I believe stock prices reflect market sentiment just as much as fundamentals. The website was founded with the goal of using simple charts and data to transform current market sentiment into important investment indicators, helping everyone overcome their irrationality and avoid chasing highs and selling lows based on emotion.
about.jsonLdDescription: Learn about the philosophy of the Sentiment Inside Out website, and how to use simple analysis tools to transform current market sentiment into important investment indicators, helping everyone overcome their own fear and greed.

indicatorItem.fearGreedTooltip: For consistent measurement across indicators, the actual value is converted to a percentile based on historical rank, serving as the Sentiment Score (0-100). Higher scores indicate more greed; lower scores indicate more fear.

marketSentiment.keywords: market sentiment, fear greed index, market sentiment indicators, investor sentiment, market thermometer, stock analysis, SPY analysis
marketSentiment.heading: Market Sentiment Analysis

error.fetchFailed: Failed to fetch market sentiment data.

composite.shortDescription: The purpose of analyzing market sentiment is to understand the current psychological state of market participants‚Äîwhether they lean towards fear or greed. This helps investors remain calm during irrational market fluctuations and avoid chasing highs or selling lows.

sections.title: Historical Data Review
sections.content: Reviewing historical data, the market sentiment index often reaches extreme fear at market bottoms and extreme greed at market tops. Using these extreme sentiments as contrarian indicators can potentially identify better buying and selling points.

sections.title: Composite Index Explanation
sections.content: The Market Sentiment Composite Index combines multiple sentiment indicators from different aspects to provide a more comprehensive market psychology thermometer. A single indicator might have noise or limitations; the composite index reflects the overall trend more smoothly.

aaiiSpread.shortDescription: The AAII Investor Sentiment Survey weekly asks members their outlook for the stock market over the next six months (bullish, bearish, neutral). The Bull-Bear Spread (bullish percentage minus bearish percentage) is a common measure of retail investor sentiment.

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: An extremely high Bull-Bear Spread (well above the historical average) usually indicates excessive market optimism and could be a potential sell signal. Conversely, an extremely low Spread (well below the historical average, even negative) indicates excessive pessimism and could be a potential buying opportunity.

sections.title: Note
sections.content: This indicator reflects retail sentiment, which is often considered a contrarian indicator. Professional investors might use extreme retail sentiment for counter-trading.

cboeRatio.shortDescription: The CBOE Put/Call Ratio is an important indicator of market speculation sentiment. It calculates the ratio of traded put option contracts to call option contracts.

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: A high Put/Call Ratio (typically above 1) indicates investors are buying more puts for hedging or bearish bets, suggesting market fear. A low Put/Call Ratio (typically below 0.7) indicates investors are buying more calls for speculation or bullish bets, suggesting market greed. Using a 5-day average smooths the data for better trend observation.

sections.title: Contrarian Indicator
sections.content: Similar to the AAII survey, extremely high Put/Call Ratios often occur at market bottoms, while extremely low ratios often occur at market tops, exhibiting contrarian characteristics.

marketMomentum.shortDescription: The Market Momentum indicator measures the S&P 500 index's position relative to its 125-day moving average (approximately the half-year line). It reflects the strength of the market's medium-term trend.

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: When the S&P 500 is significantly above its 125-day MA, it indicates a strong uptrend, strong momentum, and market greed. When the index is significantly below the MA, it indicates a downtrend, weak momentum, and market fear.

sections.title: Combine with Other Indicators
sections.content: Market momentum is a trend-following indicator and can be used in conjunction with other contrarian indicators (like the Put/Call Ratio) for a more comprehensive market assessment.

vixMA50.shortDescription: The VIX Index (Volatility Index), often called the 'fear index,' measures the market's expectation of 30-day volatility for the S&P 500. Here, we use the VIX relative to its 50-day moving average to observe changes in fear sentiment.

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: When the VIX is significantly above its 50-day MA, it indicates a sharp increase in market fear and demand for hedging, leaning towards extreme fear. When the VIX is significantly below its 50-day MA, it indicates relative market calm and higher investor risk appetite, leaning towards greed.

sections.title: Extreme Value Significance
sections.content: Extreme spikes in the VIX often accompany sharp market declines and are considered one signal for buying opportunities. However, a persistently low VIX might indicate complacency and warrant caution.

safeHaven.shortDescription: The Safe Haven Demand indicator compares the difference between the total return of Treasury bonds (safe-haven asset) and stocks (risk asset) over the past 20 trading days. It reflects the extent of fund flows into safe-haven assets.

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: When bond returns significantly outperform stock returns (high indicator value), it indicates investors are flocking to safe-haven assets, suggesting market fear. When stock returns significantly outperform bond returns (low indicator value), it indicates higher risk appetite and fund flows into risk assets, suggesting market greed.

sections.title: Observing Fund Flows
sections.content: This indicator provides a window into changes in overall market risk appetite and is an important reference for judging market sentiment.

junkBond.shortDescription: The yield spread between junk bonds (high-yield corporate bonds) and investment-grade corporate bonds reflects the market's attitude towards credit risk. Junk bonds are riskier and typically have higher yields.

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: When the spread widens (high indicator value), it means investors demand higher risk compensation to hold junk bonds. This usually happens when the market worries about economic prospects or tightening liquidity, indicating market fear. When the spread narrows (low indicator value), it means investors' risk tolerance increases, indicating market greed.

sections.title: Credit Market Signal
sections.content: The junk bond spread is an important leading indicator for observing the health of the credit market and overall market risk appetite.

cotIndex.shortDescription: The COT Index (Commitments of Traders Index), based on the weekly report from the CFTC, measures the net position (longs minus shorts) of large speculators (often considered more informed traders) in the S&P 500 futures market relative to historical levels.

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: A COT Index near 100% indicates large speculators' net long positions are at historical highs, suggesting the market might be overly bullish and leaning towards extreme greed. An index near 0% indicates net short positions are at historical highs (or net longs are extremely low), suggesting the market might be overly bearish and leaning towards extreme fear.

sections.title: Smart Money Movement
sections.content: Tracking the position changes of large speculators helps understand the outlook of the so-called 'smart money' on future market direction.

naaimIndex.shortDescription: The NAAIM Exposure Index (National Association of Active Investment Managers Exposure Index) surveys its members (active investment managers) weekly on their current equity market exposure level (0% = no stocks, 100% = fully invested, >100% = leveraged).

sections.title: Indicator Interpretation
sections.content: An extremely high exposure index (e.g., near or above 100%) indicates fund managers are generally bullish and actively holding stocks, suggesting market greed. An extremely low exposure index (e.g., near 0% or negative, indicating short positions) indicates managers are generally bearish and reducing stock holdings, suggesting market fear.

sections.title: Institutional Sentiment
sections.content: This indicator reflects the sentiment and positioning adjustments of professional investment institutions, serving as an important reference for observing the mainstream market view.

priceAnalysis.pageDescription: Analyze price trends using the characteristics of stock price mean reversion, determine if current market sentiment is overly optimistic or pessimistic, and improve entry/exit win rates.
priceAnalysis.keywords: Price Channel, Price Trend Analysis, Stock Analysis, Market Sentiment, Mean Reversion, Overbought Oversold, UL Band, Standard Deviation

jsonLd.name: Price Channel Analysis
jsonLd.description: Utilize standard deviation to analyze stock price trends and gauge market sentiment. Assess whether the current price reflects excessive optimism or pessimism. Track long-term trends and determine price position using statistical mean reversion properties.

prompt.enterSymbol: Please enter conditions and click 'Start Analysis'.

explanation.shortDescription: Analyze whether the current stock price is overly optimistic or pessimistic. Utilize the statistical properties of stock price mean reversion to track long-term trends and determine the price's position.
explanation.readMorePrefix: For detailed usage, please refer to the article:
explanation.readMoreLinkText: Analyze Price Trends and Sentiment with Price Channel

sd.title: Price Channel (Standard Deviation)
sd.l1: The middle trend line is a long-term moving average, serving as the baseline for assessing the long-term price trend. Two standard deviations are added above and below this baseline.
sd.l2: The further the price moves from the middle trend line, the further it deviates from the long-term average, increasing the probability of reverting to the trend line.
sd.l3: When the price touches the uppermost band, it indicates a strong short-term overbought condition and extreme market optimism, posing a risk of pullback.
sd.l4: When the price touches the lowermost band, it indicates a strong short-term oversold condition and extreme market pessimism, presenting an opportunity for a rebound.

ulBand.title: UL Band (Upper/Lower Band)
ulBand.l1: The UL Band is a more sensitive indicator used to help determine short-term overbought and oversold conditions.
ulBand.l2: When the price breaks above the upper UL Band, it may indicate short-term overheating.
ulBand.l3: When the price breaks below the lower UL Band, it may indicate short-term cooling.

combined.title: Using Both Together
combined.l1: When the price touches the uppermost or lowermost band of the Price Channel and simultaneously breaks the UL Band, it might signify a continuation of the trend. Consider waiting for the price to return within the UL Band before taking action.
combined.l2: It is recommended for use with index ETFs or large-cap stocks with clear trends, in conjunction with fundamental analysis. It should not be used as the sole basis for buy/sell decisions.
